from Goddard, Ives (1974), “An Outline of the Historical Phonology of Arapaho and Atsina”. International Journal of American Linguistics, 40:102 – 116
from Goddard, Ives (1974), “An Outline of the Historical Phonology of Arapaho and Atsina”. International Journal of American Linguistics, 40:102 – 116
from Goddard, Ives (1974), “An Outline of the Historical Phonology of Arapaho and Atsina”. International Journal of American Linguistics, 40:102 – 116
from Proulx, Paul (1989), “A Sketch of Blackfoot Historical Phonology”. International Journal of American Linguistics, 55:43 – 82

notes: the first obstruent of the follow[ing] cluster then becomes ʔ)

change_sets.src: from Goddard, Ives (1982), “The Historical Phonology of Munsee”. International Journal of American Linguistics, 48:16 – 48

changes.env: h_ (sometimes restored via analogy, e.g., in verbs)
_# ! some monosyllables and analogical developments, in the latter of which long vowels were shortened
_{x,h} “in the odd-numbered of any sequence of one or more short-vowel open syllables”

notes: NC sequences assimilate the nasal to the POA of the following consonant, which is then voiced

change_sets.src: from Hockett, C. F. (1981), “The Phonological History of Menominee”. Anthropological Linguistics 23(2): 51-87; and Miner, Kenneth L. (1979), “Theoretical Implications of the Great Menominee Vowel Shift”. Kansas Working Papers in Linguistics 4(1): 7-25.

changes.env: _# “[does not apply in disyllabic words containing two short vowels]”
_{k,m} “when in the second syllable of glottal words”
CC(G)_C{V,#} “[i.e., when following a cluster but not followed by a cluster. Only applies ‘after the first long vowel of a nonglottal word, and everywhere in a glottal word’]”

notes: “does not apply in the second syllable of a non-glottal word”

change_sets.src: from Costa, David J. (1991), “The Historical Phonology of Miami-Illinois Consonants”. International Journal of American Linguistics, 57:365 – 393

changes.env: #_ (and possibly in other places as well)

change_sets.or_contr: Pogostick Man with acknowledgment to dhok and Alex Fink
change_sets.src: the former citing Audrey Marie (1986), The Fundamentals of Micmac Historical Morphology, citing Hewson, John (1973), “Proto-Algonkian Reflexes in Micmac”, and Hewson, John (1983), “Some Micmac Etymologies”, and the latter citing Hewson, John (1973), “Proto-Algonkian Reflexes in Micmac”

notes: NB: For this sound-change set, H is “either an */h/ or */ʔ/, but we don’t know which”.

changes.env: C_# in disyllables with Vː or in tri(-plus-)syllables
Vː_# (Whimemsz is unsure if this change is across-the-board or not)
V[-long]{w,j}_# (Whimemsz is unsure if this change is across-the-board or not)

change_sets.src: from Mackie, Lisa (2006), “Fragments of Piscataway: A Preliminary Description”

notes: NB: This is very incomplete, partially because it seems that the only source we have on Piscataway is a single document in rather poor condition.

change_sets.src: from bin Muzaffar, Towhid, Computer Simulation of Shawnee Historical Phonology, plus “other corrections based on a few other papers plus my limited knowledge of comparative Algonquian”

changes.env: #(C)_ “(but remains e in a few cases?)”
